maml:description.maml:para: Gets Azure Automation accounts.

The Get-AzureAutomationAccount cmdlet gets the Microsoft Azure Automation accounts for your subscription. An Automation account is a container for Automation resources that is isolated from the resources of other Automation accounts. Automation resources include runbooks, jobs, and assets.
Specifies the name of an Azure Automation account.
Specifies an Azure location associated with Automation accounts.
Specifies an Azure location associated with Automation accounts.
Specifies the name of an Azure Automation account.

dev:remarks.maml:para: This command gets the Automation account named Contoso17.

maml:alert.maml:para: Keywords: azure, azuresm, servicemanagement, management, service, automation, devops

maml:description.maml:para: Gets an Azure Automation certificate.
The Get-AzureAutomationCertificate cmdlet gets one or more Microsoft Azure Automation certificates. By default, all certificates are returned. To get a specific certificate, specify its name.
Specifies the name of the automation account with the certificate.
Specifies the name of the automation account with the certificate.
Specifies the name of a certificate to retrieve.
Specifies the name of the automation account with the certificate.
Specifies the name of a certificate to retrieve.

dev:remarks.maml:para: This command gets all certificates in the Azure Automation account named Contoso17.
This command gets the certificate named MyUserCertificate.

maml:alert.maml:para: Keywords: azure, azuresm, servicemanagement, management, service, automation, devops

maml:description.maml:para: Gets an Azure Automation connection.

The Get-AzureAutomationConnection cmdlet gets one or more Microsoft Azure Automation connections. By default, all connections are returned. To get a specific connection, specify its name. To get all connections of a certain type, specify the connection type name.
Specifies the name of the automation account with the connection to retrieve.
Specifies the name of the automation account with the connection to retrieve.
Specifies the name of a connection to retrieve.
Specifies the name of the automation account with the connection to retrieve.
Specifies the name of a connection type for the connections to retrieve.
Specifies the name of the automation account with the connection to retrieve.
Specifies the name of a connection type for the connections to retrieve.
Specifies the name of a connection to retrieve.

dev:remarks.maml:para: This command gets all connections in the Automation account named Contoso17.

command:example.maml:title: Example 2: Get all connections of a type

dev:remarks.maml:para: This command gets all Azure connections in the Automation account named Contoso17.
This command gets the connection named MyConnection.

maml:description.maml:para: Gets an Azure Automation credential.
The Get-AzureAutomationCredential cmdlet gets one or more Microsoft Azure Automation credentials. By default, all credentials are returned. To get a specific credential, specify its name.
Specifies the name of the automation account with the credential to retrieve.
Specifies the name of the automation account with the credential to retrieve.
Specifies the name of a credential to retrieve.
Specifies the name of the automation account with the credential to retrieve.
Specifies the name of a credential to retrieve.

dev:remarks.maml:para: This command gets all credentials in the Automation account named Contoso17.
This command gets the credential named MyCredential.

maml:alert.maml:para: Keywords: azure, azuresm, servicemanagement, management, service, automation, devops

maml:description.maml:para: Gets one or more Azure Automation runbook jobs.
The Get-AzureAutomationJob cmdlet gets one or more runbook jobs in Microsoft Azure Automation.
Specifies the name of an Azure Automation account.
Specifies the end time for a job as a DateTime object. This cmdlet gets jobs that have an end time at or before the value that this parameter specifies.
Specifies the start time of a job as a DateTime object. This cmdlet gets jobs that have a start time at or after the value that this parameter specifies.

Specifies the status of a job. This cmdlet gets jobs that have a status matching this parameter. Valid values are:
-- Activating -- Completed -- Failed -- Queued -- Resuming -- Running -- Starting -- Stopped -- Stopping -- Suspended -- Suspending
Specifies the name of an Azure Automation account.
Specifies the ID of a job.
Specifies the name of an Azure Automation account.
Specifies the end time for a job as a DateTime object. This cmdlet gets jobs that have an end time at or before the value that this parameter specifies.
Specifies the start time of a job as a DateTime object. This cmdlet gets jobs that have a start time at or after the value that this parameter specifies.

Specifies the status of a job. This cmdlet gets jobs that have a status matching this parameter. Valid values are:
-- Activating -- Completed -- Failed -- Queued -- Resuming -- Running -- Starting -- Stopped -- Stopping -- Suspended -- Suspending
Specifies the name of a runbook.
Specifies the name of an Azure Automation account.
Specifies the end time for a job as a DateTime object. This cmdlet gets jobs that have an end time at or before the value that this parameter specifies.
Specifies the ID of a job.
Specifies the name of a runbook.

Specifies the status of a job. This cmdlet gets jobs that have a status matching this parameter. Valid values are:
-- Activating -- Completed -- Failed -- Queued -- Resuming -- Running -- Starting -- Stopped -- Stopping -- Suspended -- Suspending
Specifies the start time of a job as a DateTime object. This cmdlet gets jobs that have a start time at or after the value that this parameter specifies.

maml:description.maml:para: Gets the output of an Azure Automation job.
The Get-AzureAutomationJobOutput cmdlet gets the output of a Microsoft Azure Automation job.
Specifies the name of an Azure Automation account.
Specifies the ID of a job.
Specifies a start time as a DateTime object. The cmdlet retrieves output created after this time.

Specifies the type of output. Valid values are:
-- Any -- Debug -- Error -- Output -- Progress -- Verbose -- Warning
Specifies the name of an Azure Automation account.
Specifies the ID of a job.
Specifies a start time as a DateTime object. The cmdlet retrieves output created after this time.

Specifies the type of output. Valid values are:
-- Any -- Debug -- Error -- Output -- Progress -- Verbose -- Warning

maml:description.maml:para: Gets a runbook definition.
The Get-AzureAutomationRunbookDefinition cmdlet gets the draft definition, the published definition, or both definitions of an Azure Automation runbook. By default, the published version is returned.

maml:description.maml:para: Gets Azure Automation runbooks and associated schedules.

The Get-AzureAutomationScheduledRunbook gets one or more Azure Automation runbooks and associated schedules. By default, all scheduled runbooks are returned. To get a specific scheduled runbook, specify the runbook name and the schedule name. To get all schedules associated with a runbook, specify just the runbook name. To get all runbooks associated with a schedule, specify just the schedule name.

Specifies the Id of a scheduled job.

Specifies the name of a schedule.

Specifies the Id of a scheduled job.

The Get-AzureAutomationVariable cmdlet gets one or more Microsoft Azure Automation variables. By default, all variables are returned. To get a specific variable, specify its name.
Specifies the name of the Azure Automation account with the variable.
Specifies the name of the Azure Automation account with the variable.
Specifies the name of a variable.
Specifies the name of the Azure Automation account with the variable.
Specifies the name of a variable.

command:example.maml:title: Example 1: Get a variable
command:example.dev:code: PS C:\> $variable = Get-AzureAutomationVariable -AutomationAccountName PS C:\> "Contoso17" -Name "MyVariable" PS C:\> $value = $variable.value

dev:remarks.maml:para: These commands get an Automation variable called MyVariable and assign its value to a variable called $value.

The New-AzureAutomationAccount cmdlet creates a new automation account in Microsoft Azure Automation.

maml:alert.maml:para: Keywords: azure, azuresm, servicemanagement, management, service, automation, devops

maml:description.maml:para: Creates an Azure Automation certificate.
The New-AzureAutomationCertificate cmdlet creates a certificate in Microsoft Azure Automation. You provide the path to a certificate file to upload.
Specifies the name of the automation account the certificate will be stored in.
Specifies the name for the certificate.
Specifies the path to a script file to upload. The file can be .cer or .pfx.
A description for the certificate.
Specifies whether the certificate can be exported.
Specifies the password for the certificate file.
Specifies the name of the automation account the certificate will be stored in.
A description for the certificate.
Specifies whether the certificate can be exported.
Specifies the name for the certificate.
Specifies the password for the certificate file.
Specifies the path to a script file to upload. The file can be .cer or .pfx.

command:example.maml:title: Example 1: Create a new certificate
command:example.dev:code: PS C:\> $password = ConvertTo-SecureString "PassWord!" -AsPlainText -Force PS C:\> New-AzureAutomationCertificate -AutomationAccountName "Contos17" -Name "MyCertificate" -Path "./cert.pfx" -Password $password

dev:remarks.maml:para: These commands create a certificate in Azure Automation named MyCertificate. The first command creates the password for the certificate file that is used in the second command that creates the certificate.

maml:description.maml:para: Creates a connection in Azure Automation.
The New-AzureAutomationConnection cmdlet creates a connection in Microsoft Azure Automation.
Specifies the name of the automation account the connection will be stored in.
Specifies a name for the connection.
Specifies the name of the connection type.

Specifies a hashtable that contains key/value pairs. The keys represent the connection fields on the specified connection type. The values represent the specific values to store for each connection field for the connection instance.
Specifies a description for the credential.
Specifies the name of the automation account the connection will be stored in.

Specifies a hashtable that contains key/value pairs. The keys represent the connection fields on the specified connection type. The values represent the specific values to store for each connection field for the connection instance.

maml:alert.maml:para: Keywords: azure, azuresm, servicemanagement, management, service, automation, devops

maml:description.maml:para: Creates a credential in Azure Automation.
The New-AzureAutomationCredential cmdlet creates a credential as a PSCredential object in Microsoft Azure Automation.
Specifies the name of the automation account the credential will be stored in.
Specifies a name for the credential.
Specifies the credentials as a PSCredential object.
Specifies a description for the credential.
Specifies the name of the automation account the credential will be stored in.
Specifies a description for the credential.
Specifies a name for the credential.
Specifies the credentials as a PSCredential object.

command:example.maml:title: Example 1: Create a credential
command:example.dev:code: PS C:\> $user = "MyDomain\MyUser" PS C:\> $pw = ConvertTo-SecureString "PassWord!" -AsPlainText -Force PS C:\> $cred = New-Object â€“TypeName System.Management.Automation.PSCredential â€“ArgumentList $user, $pw PS C:\> New-AzureAutomationCredential -AutomationAccountName "Contos17" -Name "MyCredential" -Value $cred

dev:remarks.maml:para: These commands create a credential in Azure Automation named MyCredential. A credential object is first created that includes a username and password. This is then used in the last command to create the automation credential.

maml:alert.maml:para: Keywords: azure, azuresm, servicemanagement, management, service, automation, devops

maml:description.maml:para: Imports a module into Azure Automation.

The New-AzureAutomationModule cmdlet imports a module into Azure Automation. A module is a compressed file, with a .zip extension, that contains a folder which includes one of the following file types:

-- A Windows PowerShell module (psm1 file).
-- A Windows PowerShell module manifest (psd1 file).
-- An assembly (dll file)
The names of the zip file, the folder in the zip file, and file in the folder (.psm1, psd.1, or .dll) must match.
Specifies the name of the automation account the module will be stored in.
Specifies the path to the module file.
Specifies one or more tags related to the module.
Specifies the name of the automation account the module will be stored in.
Specifies the path to the module file.
Specifies one or more tags related to the module.
Microsoft.Azure.Commands.Automation.Model.Module

command:example.maml:title: Example 1: Import a module
command:example.dev:code: PS C:\> New-AzureAutomationModule â€“AutomationAccountName "Contoso17" â€“Name "ContosoModule" â€“ContentLink ".\ContosoModule.zip"

dev:remarks.maml:para: This command imports a module named ContosoModule into the Azure Automation account named Contoso17.

maml:alert.maml:para: Keywords: azure, azuresm, servicemanagement, management, service, automation, devops

maml:description.maml:para: Creates a new runbook.
The New-AzureAutomationRunbook cmdlet creates a new, empty Microsoft Azure Automation runbook. Specify a name to create a new runbook.

You can also specify the path to a Windows PowerShellÂ® script (.ps1 ) file to import a runbook. The script to import must contain a single Windows PowerShellÂ® Workflow definition. The name of this Windows PowerShell Workflow becomes the name of the runbook.
Specifies the name for the runbook.

maml:alert.maml:para: Keywords: azure, azuresm, servicemanagement, management, service, automation, devops

maml:description.maml:para: Creates an Azure Automation schedule.
The New-AzureAutomationSchedule cmdlet creates a schedule in Microsoft Azure Automation.
Specifies the name of an Azure Automation account.
Specifies a name for the schedule.
Specifies the start time of a schedule as a DateTime object. A string can be provided if it can be converted to a valid DateTime.
Specifies a description.
Specifies the expiry time of a schedule as a DateTime object. A string can be provided if it can be converted to a valid DateTime.
Specifies an interval, in days, for the schedule.
Specifies the name of an Azure Automation account.
Specifies a name for the schedule.
Specifies the start time of a schedule as a DateTime object. A string can be provided if it can be converted to a valid DateTime.
Specifies a description.
Specifies the expiry time of a schedule as a DateTime object. A string can be provided if it can be converted to a valid DateTime.
Specifies an interval, in hours, for the schedule.
Specifies the name of an Azure Automation account.
Specifies a name for the schedule.
Specifies the start time of a schedule as a DateTime object. A string can be provided if it can be converted to a valid DateTime.
Specifies a description.
Specifies that the cmdlet creates a one-time schedule.
Specifies the name of an Azure Automation account.
Specifies an interval, in days, for the schedule.
Specifies a description.
Specifies the expiry time of a schedule as a DateTime object. A string can be provided if it can be converted to a valid DateTime.
Specifies an interval, in hours, for the schedule.
Specifies a name for the schedule.
Specifies that the cmdlet creates a one-time schedule.
Specifies the start time of a schedule as a DateTime object. A string can be provided if it can be converted to a valid DateTime.

dev:remarks.maml:para: The following command creates a schedule that runs one time on the current date at 11:00 PM.

command:example.maml:title: Example 2: Create a recurring schedule
command:example.dev:code: PS C:\> $StartTime = Get-Date "13:00:00" PS C:\> $EndTime = $StartTime.AddYears(1) PS C:\> New-AzureAutomationSchedule -AutomationAccountName "Contoso17" -Name "Schedule02" -StartTime $StartTime -ExpiryTime $EndTime -DailyInterval 1

dev:remarks.maml:para: The following commands create a new schedule that runs at 1:00 PM every day for one year starting on the current day.

Specifies a name for the variable.
Specifies a value to store in the variable.

command:example.maml:title: Example 1: Create a new variable with a simple value

dev:remarks.maml:para: This command creates a new variable named MyStringVariable with a string value in the Azure Automation account named Contoso17.

command:example.maml:title: Example 2: Create a new variable with a complex value
command:example.dev:code: PS C:\> $vm = Get-AzureVM -ServiceName "MyVM" -Name "MyVM" PS C:\> New-AzureAutomationVariable -AutomationAccountName "Contoso17" -Name "MyComplexVariable" -Encrypted $false -Value $vm

dev:remarks.maml:para: These commands create a new variable called MyComplexVariable in the Azure Automation account named Contoso17. A complex object is used for its value, in this case a virtual machine object.

maml:description.maml:para: Removes an Azure Automation variable.

The Remove-AzureAutomationVariable cmdlet removes a variable from Microsoft Azure Automation. To encrypt the variable, use the Encrypted parameter. You cannot modify the encrypted state of a variable after creation. Using the Encrypted parameter on an existing, non-encrypted, variable fails.
Specifies the name of the automation account with the variable.
Specifies the name of the variable.
Forces the command to run without asking for user confirmation.
Specifies the name of the automation account with the variable.
Forces the command to run without asking for user confirmation.
Specifies the name of the variable.

dev:remarks.maml:para: This command removes a variable named MyStringVariable in the Azure Automation account named Contoso17 without prompting for user validation.

maml:alert.maml:para: Keywords: azure, azuresm, servicemanagement, management, service, automation, devops

maml:description.maml:para: Resumes a suspended Azure Automation job.
The Resume-AzureAutomationJob cmdlet resumes a suspended Microsoft Azure Automation job. Specify the suspended job.
To suspend a job, use the Suspend-AzureAutomationJob cmdlet.
Specifies the name of an Azure Automation account.
Specifies the ID of a job.
Specifies the name of an Azure Automation account.
Specifies the ID of a job.

dev:remarks.maml:para: This command resumes the job that has the specified ID.

maml:alert.maml:para: Keywords: azure, azuresm, servicemanagement, management, service, automation, devops

maml:description.maml:para: Modifies the configuration of an Azure Automation certificate.
The Set-AzureAutomationCertificate cmdlet modifies the configuration of a certificate in Microsoft Azure Automation.
Specifies the name of the automation account with the certificate.
The name of the certificate.
A description for the certificate.
Specifies whether the certificate can be exported.
The password for the certificate file.
The path to a script file to upload. The file can be .cer or .pfx.
Specifies the name of the automation account with the certificate.
A description for the certificate.
Specifies whether the certificate can be exported.
The name of the certificate.
The password for the certificate file.
The path to a script file to upload. The file can be .cer or .pfx.

command:example.maml:title: Example 1: Update a certificate
command:example.dev:code: PS C:\> $password = ConvertTo-SecureString "PassWord!" -AsPlainText -Force PS C:\> Set-AzureAutomationCertificate -AutomationAccountName "Contos17" -Name "MyCertificate" -Path "./cert.pfx" -Password $password

dev:remarks.maml:para: These commands update an existing certificate in Azure Automation named MyCertificate. The first command creates the password for the certificate file that is used in the second command that updates the certificate.

The Set-AzureAutomationConnectionFieldValue cmdlet modifies the value for a field in a connection in Azure Automation.

Specifies a name for the connection.
Specifies a name for the field.
Specifies a value to store in the connection field.

Specifies a name for the field.

maml:description.maml:para: Modifies a credential in Azure Automation.
The Set-AzureAutomationCredential cmdlet modifies a credential as a PSCredential object in Microsoft Azure Automation.
Specifies the name of the automation account with the credential.
Specifies the name of the credential.
Specifies a description for the credential.
Specifies the credentials as a PSCredential object.
Specifies the name of the automation account with the credential.
Specifies a description for the credential.
Specifies the name of the credential.
Specifies the credentials as a PSCredential object.

command:example.maml:title: Example 1: Update a credential
command:example.dev:code: PS C:\> $user = "MyDomain\MyUser" PS C:\> $pw = ConvertTo-SecureString "PassWord!" -AsPlainText -Force PS C:\> $cred = New-Object â€“TypeName System.Management.Automation.PSCredential â€“ArgumentList $user, $pw PS C:\> New-AzureAutomationCredential -AutomationAccountName "Contos17" -Name "MyCredential" -Value $cred

dev:remarks.maml:para: These commands update an existing credential in Azure Automation named MyCredential. A credential object is first created that includes a username and password. This is then used in the last command to update the automation credential.

maml:alert.maml:para: Keywords: azure, azuresm, servicemanagement, management, service, automation, devops

maml:description.maml:para: Updates a module in Azure Automation.
The Set-AzureAutomationModule cmdlet imports a new version of a module or changes the configuration of the module in Azure Automation.
Specifies the name of the automation account with the module.
Specifies the path to the module file.
Specifies the version of the module.
Specifies the name of the automation account with the module.
Specifies the path to the module file.
Specifies the version of the module.
Microsoft.Azure.Commands.Automation.Model.Module

command:example.maml:title: Example 1: Update a module
command:example.dev:code: PS C:\> Set-AzureAutomationModule â€“AutomationAccountName "Contoso17" â€“Name "ContosoModule" â€“ContentLinkUri ".\ContosoModule.zip" â€“ContentLinkVersion "1.1"

dev:remarks.maml:para: This command imports an updated version of an existing module named ContosoModule into the Azure Automation account named Contoso17.

maml:description.maml:para: Updates the draft definition of a runbook.

The Set-AzureAutomationRunbookDefinition cmdlet updates the draft definition of a Microsoft Azure Automation runbook. Provide a Windows PowerShellÂ® script (.ps1) file that contains a runbook which becomes the draft runbook. If a draft already exists, use the Overwrite parameter to force the cmdlet to overwrite the existing draft.

command:example.maml:title: Example 1: Overwrite an existing draft definition of a runbook

dev:remarks.maml:para: This command overwrites the existing draft definition of a runbook.

maml:description.maml:para: Modifies an Azure Automation variable.

The Set-AzureAutomationVariable cmdlet modifies the value or description of a variable in Microsoft Azure Automation. To encrypt the variable, use the Encrypted parameter. You cannot modify the encrypted state of a variable after creation. Using the Encrypted parameter on an existing, non-encrypted, variable fails.
Specifies the name of the automation account with the variable.
Specifies the name of the variable.
Specifies a value for the variable.
Specifies a description for the variable.

maml:description.maml:para: Starts a runbook job.
The Start-AzureAutomationRunbook cmdlet starts a Microsoft Azure Automation runbook job. Specify the ID or name of a runbook.

The Stop-AzureAutomationJob cmdlet stops a Microsoft Azure Automation job. Specify a running automation job.

Specifies the ID of a job.

maml:description.maml:para: Suspends an Azure Automation job.
The Suspend-AzureAutomationJob cmdlet suspends a Microsoft Azure Automation job. Specify a running Automation job.

Specifies the ID of a job.
Specifies the name of an Azure Automation account.
Specifies the ID of a job.

maml:description.maml:para: Removes an association between a runbook and a schedule.

The Unregister-AzureAutomationScheduledRunbook cmdlet removes the association between a Microsoft Azure Automation runbook and a schedule, which stops the runbook from starting when the schedule fires.
Specifies the name of an Azure Automation account.
Specifies the name of a runbook.
Specifies the name of a schedule.
Specifies the name of an Azure Automation account.
Specifies the ID of a scheduled runbook.
Specifies the name of an Azure Automation account.
Specifies the ID of a scheduled runbook.
Specifies the name of a runbook.
Specifies the name of a schedule.

dev:remarks.maml:para: This command removes the association between the runbook named Runbk01 and the schedule named Runbk01Sched.
